description: From Medieval Latin eleemosynarius (“alms dispenser”), from Late Latin eleemosyna (“alms”), from Ancient Greek ἐλεημοσύνη (eleēmosúnē, “alms”), from ἐλεέω (eleéō, “I have mercy”), from ἔλεος (éleos, “pity”). Compare Italian elemosina.

adjectives.description: eleemosynary (comparative more eleemosynary, superlative most eleemosynary)

entries.meaning: Relating to charity, alms, or almsgiving.
examples: He did some work for the New York Public Library . . . and also dabbled in eleemosynary science for the Russell Sage Foundation.

entries.meaning: Given in charity or alms; having the nature of alms
examples: His spirited refusal of an eleemosynary supply of shoes, arose, no doubt, from a proper pride.

Amidst all this, the legal business, the acquiring of land, the construction of the Montgomery Block, Billings had generosity and time to support the founding of the University of California and a half dozen churches, schools, orphan asylums and other eleemosynary institutions.
